title: Why are umbrellas used for photography? - Quora

response.answer_text: There are many types of lighting systems for the studio.Using umbrella is one type.Umbrella is basically used to bounce back the light from the elinchrom.In this,the curvature of the umbrella is more prominent and the layer of the umbrella would be a reflective layer(silvery in texture and look) and also white coloured umbrella are available & used,depending upon the lighting setup you prefer for the object ,you're going to shoot.Trigger is the device that is mounted on the top of the camera in its slot. Trigger controls all the lighting instruments in it.The intensity of light(temperature) to flash is at the back of the lighting device.You can adjust it depending upon the intensity you need.when the trigger in the camera is activated ,when you press the shutter button the signal gets to the lighting instruments and light starts to flash on the objectYou have to mount the umbrella in such a way that no shadows should fall behind the object at any angle. Umbrella is mounted to a tripod and the light will be facing towards umbrella's inner curvature.steadily towards the centre of the umbrella .“Catchlight: Light that reflects in a subject’s eyes and adds life to the portrait. Either a flash or reflector panel is used to create catchlight.”— Canon, “Flash Terminology”

It is used to soften the effect of flash. To provide proper lighting to the subject and the surroundings, flash lights are used. Since using the flashlight directly often leads to intense and unnatural light, it is not recommended, at least not for professional photos. To make the light from the flash seem mkre natural, less intense and evenly distributed, photographers use umbrellas as the translucent stuff they're made of allow the light to pass in a way that it meets the above criteria. Apart from this, umbrellas can also help in directing light in specific directions like for when  you want to light a particular side of face.
